articles.headline: In 2013: Rebounds, Traders and Rights
articles.snippet: A look back at a year of change at Netflix and Exxon Mobil, the continuing insider trading case at SAC Capital Advisors and a bruising yet profitable year at Tesla Motors.
articles.abstract: A look back at a year of change at Netflix and Exxon Mobil, the continuing insider trading case at SAC Capital Advisors and a bruising yet profitable year at Tesla Motors.
articles.lead_paragraph: What a difference a year has made for Reed Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix.

articles.headline: Judge Upholds N.S.A.’s Bulk Collection of Data on Calls
articles.snippet: The judge’s ruling was the latest contribution to a debate among courts and a presidential review group about how to balance security and privacy in the era of big data.
articles.abstract: The judge’s ruling was the latest contribution to a debate among courts and a presidential review group about how to balance security and privacy in the era of big data.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Friday ruled that a National Security Agency program that collects enormous troves of phone records is legal, making the latest contribution to an extraordinary debate among courts and a presidential review group about how to balance security and privacy in the era of big data.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Target’s Nightmare Goes On: Encrypted PIN Data Stolen
articles.snippet: On Friday, Target confirmed that cybercriminals had managed to steal encrypted PIN data for its customers, in what is officially the second largest breach of a retailer in history.
articles.abstract: On Friday, Target confirmed that cybercriminals had managed to steal encrypted PIN data for its customers, in what is officially the second largest breach of a retailer in history.
articles.lead_paragraph: After hackers stole credit and debit card records for 40 million Target store customers, the retailer said customers’ personal identification numbers, or PINs, had not been breached.

articles.headline: Markets on Edge as China Moves to Curb Risky Lending
articles.snippet: Beijing has pledged to deliver the country’s most sweeping financial overhaul in decades, liberalizing interest rates and welcoming investment, but the effort is putting stress on the banking system.
articles.abstract: Beijing has pledged to deliver the country’s most sweeping financial overhaul in decades, liberalizing interest rates and welcoming investment, but the effort is putting stress on the banking system.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s financial system is in danger of becoming too big to bail out.
articles.byline: By Neil Gough and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: At Lloyds, a Bank and Its Boss on the Rebound
articles.snippet: The Lloyds Banking Group’s chief executive, António Horta-Osório, has steered the bailed-out bank to recovery by concentrating almost exclusively on its home market in Britain.
articles.abstract: The Lloyds Banking Group’s chief executive, António Horta-Osório, has steered the bailed-out bank to recovery by concentrating almost exclusively on its home market in Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: António Horta-Osório was eight months into his new job as chief executive of the Lloyds Banking Group in 2011, wrestling with a plan to refocus the British lender, when he stopped sleeping.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Aiming to Reinvent Itself, Panasonic Moves Beyond the Living Room
articles.snippet: As it backs away from consumer electronics, Panasonic is focusing on two less visible but more profitable areas — homes and cars.
articles.abstract: As it backs away from consumer electronics, Panasonic is focusing on two less visible but more profitable areas — homes and cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: FUJISAWA, Japan — Panasonic used to make televisions, refrigerators and computer monitors in this suburb of Tokyo. Now, six years after closing its factories in Fujisawa, the company is building homes on the site, which is sandwiched between Mount Fuji and the Pacific.

articles.headline: Turkey Legs Conquer Land of Mouse Ears
articles.snippet: Unleashing their inner cave dweller, Disney guests will eat as many as two million of the theme parks’ giant smoked turkey legs in 2013.
articles.abstract: Unleashing their inner cave dweller, Disney guests will eat as many as two million of the theme parks’ giant smoked turkey legs in 2013.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — It made its humble debut at a single stand in the late 1980s next to Big Al’s Coonskin Caps in Frontierland. Slowly it spread — dripping, always dripping — beyond Walt Disney World here to Disneyland in California.

articles.headline: Loyal Subscribers Keep Hobby Magazines Afloat
articles.snippet: Some high-end hobby magazines have experienced steady circulation growth even as costs rise, and raise more revenue with special events for subscribers.
articles.abstract: Some high-end hobby magazines have experienced steady circulation growth even as costs rise, and raise more revenue with special events for subscribers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lance Prucnal’s family, like others in the digital age, has canceled most of its newspaper and magazine subscriptions.

articles.headline: Benefits Ending for One Million Unemployed
articles.snippet: A federal emergency program, in place since 2008, had provided up to 47 weeks of supplemental unemployment insurance payments to jobless Americans looking for work.
articles.abstract: A federal emergency program, in place since 2008, had provided up to 47 weeks of supplemental unemployment insurance payments to jobless Americans looking for work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An emergency federal program that acts as a lifeline for 1.3 million jobless workers will end on Saturday, drastically curtailing government support for the long-term unemployed and setting the stage for a major political fight in the new year.

articles.headline: Academics Who Defend Wall St. Reap Reward
articles.snippet: Wall Street paid academic experts — and gave money to their universities — whose research supported the financial community’s views on commodity trading.
articles.abstract: Wall Street paid academic experts — and gave money to their universities — whose research supported the financial community’s views on commodity trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: Signs of the energy business are inescapable in and around Houston — the pipelines, refineries and tankers that crowd the harbor, and the gleaming office towers where oil companies and energy traders have transformed the skyline.

articles.headline: Police Salaries and Pensions Push California City to Brink
articles.snippet: Desert Hot Springs is sliding into bankruptcy for familiar reasons: unrealistic revenue estimates and too-generous pension promises to city workers.
articles.abstract: Desert Hot Springs is sliding into bankruptcy for familiar reasons: unrealistic revenue estimates and too-generous pension promises to city workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DESERT HOT SPRINGS, Calif. — Emerging from Los Angeles’s vast eastern sprawl, the freeway glides over a narrow pass and slips gently into the scrubby, palm-flecked Coachella Valley.
articles.byline: By Rick Lyman and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: The Merchant of Just Be Happy
articles.snippet: The life coach Martha Beck has made a lot of money from a simple theme: If it feels right, go for it. She wants both women and men to conquer the “soul-sucking” forces around them.
articles.abstract: The life coach Martha Beck has made a lot of money from a simple theme: If it feels right, go for it. She wants both women and men to conquer the “soul-sucking” forces around them.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a cool mid-September afternoon at the California horse ranch of the life coach Martha Beck, two blindfolded, crouching men came to an impasse. The men had been told to think of themselves as animals and to use only their sense of hearing to try to locate and tag each other — all in an effort to awaken the senses and instincts presumably deadened by desk jobs and smartphones.

articles.headline: Clawbacks? They’re Still a Rare Breed
articles.snippet: Under the Sarbanes-Oxley law, regulators must clear many hurdles before executives can be required to forfeit pay.
articles.abstract: Under the Sarbanes-Oxley law, regulators must clear many hurdles before executives can be required to forfeit pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Financial executives who are actually held to account for misdeeds remain as rare as hen’s teeth, alas. That’s why a recent enforcement action by the Securities and Exchange Commission caught my eye.

articles.headline: Signs of a Russian Thaw (Toward Business)
articles.snippet: In a country where entrepreneurs are scorned (or worse), an influential voice is speaking up for them — carefully.
articles.abstract: In a country where entrepreneurs are scorned (or worse), an influential voice is speaking up for them — carefully.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was just after 9 on a mid-May morning in 2011 when Ruslan Telkov got into his car and headed toward one of his upholstery company’s warehouses near Moscow. His parents had warned him not to start his own business, that only frustration and heartache awaited, if not worse. But it was not the 1990s anymore, he told them; the days of bandit capitalism in Russia were over. “I decided it’s what I wanted, and that was that,” he said.

articles.headline: West Virginia Democrats Face an Uneasy Time
articles.snippet: Long a backbone of the Democratic Party, West Virginia has an accelerating rightward tilt that could affect next year’s Senate race.
articles.abstract: Long a backbone of the Democratic Party, West Virginia has an accelerating rightward tilt that could affect next year’s Senate race.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — Although Democrats have owned West Virginia’s two Senate seats since the Eisenhower administration, Republicans are eyeing this state as one of their best bets as they seek to win a Senate majority next year.

articles.headline: A Civil Servant in Mexico Tests U.S. on Asylum
articles.snippet: Mexican officials have become frustrated by a local official who has provided residents with letters describing their area’s drug violence to help them seek asylum in the United States.
articles.abstract: Mexican officials have become frustrated by a local official who has provided residents with letters describing their area’s drug violence to help them seek asylum in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA RUANA, Mexico — Jittery families cram into his tiny office here, daily. Hundreds more have appeared at the San Diego border 1,500 miles away, clutching an official-looking letter bearing his name, gambling that its description of the violence in this blistering stretch of central Mexico will help them gain asylum in the United States.

articles.headline: Deadly Mix in Benghazi: False Allies, Crude Video
articles.snippet: The reality behind the deadly attack on American outposts in Libya is murkier and more complex than initially believed.
articles.abstract: The reality behind the deadly attack on American outposts in Libya is murkier and more complex than initially believed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — A boyish-looking American diplomat was meeting for the first time with the Islamist leaders of eastern Libya’s most formidable militias.

articles.headline: Bombings Jolt Russia, Raising Olympic Fears
articles.snippet: The explosion struck the main station in Volgograd, raising the specter of terrorism ahead of the Winter Olympics.
articles.abstract: The explosion struck the main station in Volgograd, raising the specter of terrorism ahead of the Winter Olympics.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A deadly suicide bombing at a crowded railroad station in southern Russia on Sunday, followed by a blast in a trolley bus on Monday in the same city, raised the specter of a new wave of terrorism just six weeks before the Winter Olympics in Sochi.

articles.headline: Roughed Up by an Orca? There’s a Code for That
articles.snippet: A new catalog of medical billing codes will have 68,000 for diagnoses alone, beginning Oct. 1. The medical informatics business is bracing itself.
articles.abstract: A new catalog of medical billing codes will have 68,000 for diagnoses alone, beginning Oct. 1. The medical informatics business is bracing itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: Know someone who drowned from jumping off burning water skis? Well, there’s a new medical billing code for that.

articles.headline: Time Inc. Is Preparing to Head Out on Its Own
articles.snippet: Time Warner is joining other media conglomerates in pushing to compartmentalize their publishing units during a fragile time for the industry.
articles.abstract: Time Warner is joining other media conglomerates in pushing to compartmentalize their publishing units during a fragile time for the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Time Inc., the largest magazine publisher in the United States, with properties like People, Sports Illustrated and Fortune, is preparing for one of the most pivotal periods in its 91-year history.

articles.headline: U.S. Struggles to Keep Pace in Delivering Broadband Service
articles.snippet: The United States is falling dangerously behind in offering high-speed, affordable broadband service, according to technology experts and recent studies.
articles.abstract: The United States is falling dangerously behind in offering high-speed, affordable broadband service, according to technology experts and recent studies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — San Antonio is the seventh-largest city in the United States, a progressive and economically vibrant metropolis of 1.4 million people sprawled across south-central Texas. But the speed of its Internet service is no match for the Latvian capital, Riga, a city of 700,000 on the Baltic Sea.

articles.headline: On Defensive, JPMorgan Hired China’s Elite
articles.snippet: Competitive pressures drove many of JPMorgan’s decisions to ramp up its “Sons and Daughters” hiring program, emails and documents show.
articles.abstract: Competitive pressures drove many of JPMorgan’s decisions to ramp up its “Sons and Daughters” hiring program, emails and documents show.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a series of late-night emails, JPMorgan Chase executives in Hong Kong lamented the loss of a lucrative assignment.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Democrats Turn to Minimum Wage as 2014 Strategy
articles.snippet: Democrats are hoping that a push to raise the federal minimum wage and a campaign to place state-level wage proposals on the ballot will help their chances in hotly contested congressional races.
articles.abstract: Democrats are hoping that a push to raise the federal minimum wage and a campaign to place state-level wage proposals on the ballot will help their chances in hotly contested congressional races.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democratic Party leaders, bruised by months of attacks on the new health care program, have found an issue they believe can lift their fortunes both locally and nationally in 2014: an increase in the minimum wage.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Rise in Twitter’s Stock Reflects Exuberance in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: Tech stocks may not quite have returned to the anything-goes dot-com era, but Twitter shares’ rapid rise is a sign of giddiness in the industry.
articles.abstract: Tech stocks may not quite have returned to the anything-goes dot-com era, but Twitter shares’ rapid rise is a sign of giddiness in the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Max Ganik has no doubts that Twitter’s stock — up 145 percent since it first began trading on Nov. 7 — is firmly in bubble territory.

articles.headline: Bomb Attacks in Russia Echo Threats by Chechen Insurgent
articles.snippet: Two terrorist attacks in Volgograd have sowed widespread fear across the country, and the attention of Russian security services has turned to the insurgent leader, Doku Umarov.
articles.abstract: Two terrorist attacks in Volgograd have sowed widespread fear across the country, and the attention of Russian security services has turned to the insurgent leader, Doku Umarov.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Twin terrorist attacks in the city of Volgograd within 24 hours injected new urgency on Monday into Russia’s long, ruthless effort to contain a diffuse Islamic insurgency on its southern border, one nominally led by a veteran, battle-scarred Chechen often called Russia’s Osama bin Laden.

articles.headline: China Says Local-Level Debt Soars, Stirring Fear
articles.snippet: A report from the National Audit Office says debt rose 12.7% in six months, which is likely to further raise concerns about China’s borrowing.
articles.abstract: A report from the National Audit Office says debt rose 12.7% in six months, which is likely to further raise concerns about China’s borrowing.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The total debt of local governments in China has soared to nearly $3 trillion as the country’s addiction to credit-fueled growth has deepened in recent years, according to the findings of a long-awaited report released on Monday by the central auditing agency.
